cityPageContent.complianceSection:
Florida is recognized as having some of the strongest consumer protections for payday loans in the United States. Under Florida law, cash advance loans (officially called 'Deferred Presentment Transactions') are legal but heavily regulated by the Florida Office of Financial Regulation. Residents of {{city}} benefit from these comprehensive state protections.

Florida law caps single-payment payday loans at $500 with a maximum fee of 10% of the loan amount, plus a $5 verification fee. This means on a $500 loan, you would pay no more than $55 in fees. For installment payday loans, the maximum is $1,000 with fees capped at 8% of the outstanding balance on a biweekly basis. All lenders must comply with federal Truth-in-Lending Act disclosure requirements, ensuring you understand the total cost before you borrow.

One of Florida's most important protections is the 'one loan at a time' rule. You cannot have more than one payday loan outstanding anywhere in Florida, and you must wait 24 hours after paying off one loan before taking out another. This is enforced through a mandatory statewide database that all licensed lenders must check. Additionally, loan rollovers and extensions are strictly prohibited, preventing the debt trap cycles common in states with weaker regulations.
cityPageContent.consumerProtectionText:
If you find yourself unable to repay your payday loan on time, Florida law provides a safety net. For single-payment loans, if you inform your lender in person that you cannot pay in full, you are entitled to a 60-day grace period at no additional cost. To qualify, you must make an appointment with a nonprofit credit counseling agency within 7 days and complete the counseling within 60 days. Your lender is required to provide you with a list of approved agencies. For installment loans, you can defer one payment to the end of your loan term without any additional fees by notifying your lender by noon the business day before the payment is due.

Florida law also protects you from criminal prosecution for an unpaid payday loan check, though lenders may pursue civil collection remedies. Lenders are prohibited from requiring additional security, wage assignments, or forcing you to waive your legal rights. They cannot collect fees upfront and cannot charge prepayment penalties if you want to pay off your loan early. All payday lenders operating in {{city}} must be licensed by the Florida Office of Financial Regulation, and you can verify their license status online or by calling (850) 487-9687.
disclaimers: This information is provided for general educational purposes only and should not be construed as legal or financial advice.
Payday loan laws and regulations are subject to change. This information was last verified on January 15, 2025, and may not reflect the most current legal developments.
For the most accurate and up-to-date information about Florida payday loan regulations, please contact the Florida Office of Financial Regulation at (850) 487-9687 or visit flofr.gov.

If you are considering a payday loan, we strongly recommend exploring alternatives such as payment plans with creditors, credit counseling, community assistance programs, or small loans from credit unions.
Consult with a licensed financial advisor or attorney regarding your specific situation before making borrowing decisions.
While payday loans can provide quick access to cash in emergencies, they come with high costs and should only be used when all other options have been exhausted.
keyPoints: All payday lenders in Florida must be licensed by the Florida Office of Financial Regulation
You can only have one payday loan at a time in Florida, enforced by statewide database
Single-payment loans are capped at $500 with maximum 10% fee plus $5 verification fee
Installment loans are capped at $1,000 with maximum 8% biweekly fee on outstanding balance
You must wait 24 hours after paying off one loan before taking out another
Loan rollovers and extensions are prohibited by law
If you can't pay on time, you're entitled to a 60-day grace period with free credit counseling
You cannot be criminally prosecuted for an unpaid payday loan
Prepayment penalties are prohibited - you can pay off early without extra cost
All lenders must provide Truth-in-Lending Act disclosures showing total cost and APR

cityPageContent.warningAboutUnregulatedProducts: Be aware that some financial products marketed as alternatives to payday loans, such as 'Earned Wage Access' apps and 'Buy Now Pay Later' services, are NOT regulated under Florida's consumer protection laws. These unregulated products may not have the same caps on fees, interest rates, or protections against multiple loans. The Florida CFO has issued consumer alerts warning that these products can lead to dangerous debt cycles without the safeguards that protect Florida payday loan borrowers.

comparisonToOtherStates.comparedToTexas: Much stricter - Texas has no APR caps and allows CAB model with unlimited fees; Florida caps fees at 10% for single-payment loans
comparisonToOtherStates.comparedToCalifornia: Similar - both cap rates around 30-36% APR and prohibit rollovers
comparisonToOtherStates.comparedToColorado: Less strict - Colorado caps at 36% APR; Florida's fees result in 260-456% APR
comparisonToOtherStates.ranking: Florida ranks in the middle tier nationally - stronger than states with no caps (TX, NV, UT) but less restrictive than states with 36% APR caps (CO, IL, NY)
